title: How to Score Your Hand in Cribbage

steps.title: Place a card face up from your hand onto the table.
steps.content: Place a card face up from your hand onto the table. Decide who gets to go first by picking a dealer. Whoever is sitting left of the dealer gets to go first. Have each player take a turn putting a card face-up on the table from their hand. You can only choose cards from your hand of 4, not from the 2 you discarded at the beginning of the round. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Add the face-up card values together to keep a running total.
steps.content: Add the face-up card values together to keep a running total. As everyone lays down their cards, keep a running total of the amount that you have set face-up on the table. Cards with numbers on them are worth their numerical value, face cards are worth 10 points, and aces are worth 1 point. [2] X Research source Everyone who is playing is responsible for counting the running total out loud whenever they put a card down.

steps.title: Avoid exceeding a running total of 31 with each card.
steps.content: Avoid exceeding a running total of 31 with each card. As you count the total of the cards, your objective is to not exceed 31 total. Add your card number in your head to the current total, and if it exceeds 31, don’t put it down. [3] X Research source If you exceed 31, your opponent gets 1 point, and vice versa.

steps.title: Score a point if your opponent can't place a card without exceeding 31.
steps.content: Score a point if your opponent can't place a card without exceeding 31. If you or your opponent can’t put down a card, say “Go.” The person who did not say “Go” gets to move their peg 1 hole on the board closer to the end. [4] X Research source Whoever lays down the final card in the running total gets 1 extra point.

steps.title: Score additional points for pairs and multiples of the same rank.
steps.content: Score additional points for pairs and multiples of the same rank. If you put down a 7 and your opponent follows with a 7, this is a pair, and your opponent earns 2 points, moving them 2 spaces. This is called a “pair.” If you make 3 of a kind, you get 4 points. If you make 4 of a kind, you get 12 points. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Count extra points for runs.
steps.content: Count extra points for runs. If you put down a 3 and your opponent follows with a 4, this is a 2-card run, which earns them 2 points or spaces. This is called a “double run.” If you have 3 cards in a run, like, 3, 4, and 5, it’s a triple run, and 4 cards in a run is a quadruple run. [6] X Research source Runs don’t necessarily have to be in order. For example, if you put down a 3, your opponent puts down a 5, and then you put down a 4, that counts as a run of 3 and you’d get 3 points. The amount of points you get depends on how many cards are in the run.

steps.title: Score 2 extra points if the running total becomes 15.
steps.content: Score 2 extra points if the running total becomes 15. If you put down a card and it brings the running total to 15, you get to move 2 spaces on the peg board. The running total has to be exactly 15, not above or below. [7] X Research source

steps.title: End the round when the cards run out.
steps.content: End the round when the cards run out. A cribbage round is officially over when all of the cards that could have been played from each hand are on the table. Have each player gather their hands to start counting them up. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Start with the player to the left of the dealer.
steps.content: Start with the player to the left of the dealer. Have each player count their hand one at a time. Make sure the dealer goes last and that everyone checks each other’s math as they go. [9] X Research source It may be helpful to count your points out loud so that everyone can hear them.

steps.title: Count the starter card towards your hand as you count.
steps.content: Count the starter card towards your hand as you count. At the beginning of the round, the dealer flipped over a card and left it face-up on the table. Have each player count this card like it’s in their own hand to give everyone more points. [10] X Research source This card is also called the starter card. Keep track of your scores on a notepad.

steps.title: Count each card combination that adds up to 15 as 2 points.
steps.content: Count each card combination that adds up to 15 as 2 points. If any of your cards can add up to 15, write that down as 2 points for each total of 15. Make sure you check your math, because you could lose points if you are wrong. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Add up runs and give them points based on how long they are.
steps.content: Add up runs and give them points based on how long they are. A run, or cards that are in numerical order, are scored based on how many cards are in each run. For example, if you have cards 5, 6, and 7, that is 3 points, or a triple run. If you have cards 2 and 3, that’s 2 points, or a double run. [12] X Research source Remember to use the starter card to make runs for extra points.

steps.title: Score points for pairs and multiples of the same rank.
steps.content: Score points for pairs and multiples of the same rank. Pairs are cards that have the same number or face. For example, if you have 2 Kings, give yourself 2 points. You can get more points if there are 3 or 4 cards of the same kind. For example, if you have 4 aces, give yourself 4 points. [13] X Research source Add the starter card to give yourself more points in each pair.

steps.title: Give yourself 4 points if all the cards in your hand are the same suit.
steps.content: Give yourself 4 points if all the cards in your hand are the same suit. If your cards are all the same suit, like hearts, spades, clubs, and diamonds, you get to add 4 points to your total. If the starter card is also the same suit as your 4 cards, you get 5 points. [14] X Research source This is called a flush.

steps.title: Add 1 point if you have a Jack that matches the suit of the flipped card.
steps.content: Add 1 point if you have a Jack that matches the suit of the flipped card. There’s a special rule called a “nob” that gives you an extra point. For example, if you have a Jack in your hand that’s a spade, and the starter card is a spade as well, give yourself an extra point. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Count the crib and give yourself the points if you are the dealer.
steps.content: Count the crib and give yourself the points if you are the dealer. Whoever dealt the cards in this round gets to count up the “crib,” or 2 cards that each player discarded at the beginning of the round. The dealer gets points for the flushes, nobs, pairs, or runs in the crib and can add them to their own total. [16] X Research source Alternate who is dealing so that each player gets to count the crib as their own at least once.

steps.title: Keep going until someone reaches 121 points.
steps.content: Keep going until someone reaches 121 points. Each cribbage pegboard has 120 spaces, so the first person to travel around the peg board plus 1 extra point wins the game. This is also called “pegging out.” [17] X Research source
